item.title: Online Services Again Abused to Exfiltrate Data, (Tue, Apr 15th)
item.source: SANS Internet Storm Center, InfoCON: green
item.content:encoded: If Attackers can abuse free online services, they will do for sure! Why spend time to deploy a C2 infrastructure if you have plenty of ways to use "official" services. Not only, they don't cost any money but the traffic can be hidden in the normal traffic; making them more difficult to detect. A very popular one was anonfiles[.]com. It was so abused that they closed in 2023![1]. A funny fact is that I still see lot of malicious scripts that refer to this domain. Of course, alternatives popped up here and there, like anonfile[.]la[2].

item.title: xorsearch.py: Searching With Regexes, (Mon, Apr 14th)
item.source: SANS Internet Storm Center, InfoCON: green
item.content:encoded: As promised in diary entry "XORsearch: Searching With Regexes", I will outline another method to search with xorsearch and regexes.

item.title: Slow Pisces Targets Developers With Coding Challenges and Introduces New Customized Python Malware
item.author: Prashil Pattni
item.content:encoded: North Korean state-sponsored group Slow Pisces (Jade Sleet) targeted crypto developers with a social engineering campaign that included malicious coding challenges.

item.title: Exploit Attempts for Recent Langflow AI Vulnerability (CVE-2025-3248), (Sat, Apr 12th)
item.source: SANS Internet Storm Center, InfoCON: green
item.content:encoded: Two weeks ago, version 1.3.0 of Langflow was released. The release notes list many fixes but do not mention that one of the "Bug Fixes" addresses a major vulnerability. Instead, the release notes state, "auth current user on code validation." [1]
